body:
I can confirm this bug on Linux Mint as well.

Note: I've updated the provided code to use `Window` instead of `RenderWindow` to make it even more minimal. Additionally, the fact that `window` is global isn't the issue: it's arguable bad design but using a local variable and references results in the same bug.
I tried to have `sf::Window` as an `std::unique_ptr` and reallocate it with `std::make_unique<sf::Window>` every time `createWindow()` is called but the result is same which makes it pretty weird.
So it's the same even if you create two separate windows?

If I remove the `window.setKeyRepeatEnabled(false);` line, it's true by default.

Holding a button prints like,
```
KeyPressed: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyReleased: 4
```

Then I call the createWindow() again, and hold a button, it prints like:


```
KeyPressed: 4
KeyReleased: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyReleased: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyReleased: 4
KeyPressed: 4
KeyReleased: 4
```
@texus I don't know how good that patch is, but if you provide a PR we could test it easily. :-)

issue.title: Improved method used to filter KeyRelease in X11
issue.body:
This should fix #1223.

The event behind KeyRelease is now only retrieved from the same window. Because peeking did not work well, the event is instead removed from the queue and put back afterwards (unless the event is KeyPress and key repeating is disabled).

body: Ok, the patch is found in PR #1230.
